   Assessment and Plan
   83 y.o woman with history of chronic systolic CHF with 2 week history
   of generalized weakness and shortness of breath, recently admitted to
   [**Hospital3 **] now transferred here to [**Hospital1 1**] for management of her
   heart failure and now new afib with RVR. She continues to be
   hypotensive despite rate control now with increasing leukocytosis,
   concerning for septic shock.
   .
   # MR: patient was found to have [**Hospital1 10146**] tear at posterior leaflet of
   mitral valve, likely contributing to worsening MR.  [**Name14 (STitle) 10146**] tear is
   likely a consequence of chronic history of MVP.  MR is likely
   contributing to her afib.
   - contact [**Name (NI) 10147**] for MVR
   - be gentle on IVF to avoid flash pulmonary edema
   - would avoid pressor if MAP>50 to avoid increased afterload which
   could make MR worse
   .
   # Hypotension: Unclear etiology but this is likely a combination of
   afib with RVR, sepsis, and heart failure from severe MR (shown on TTE
   on [**2129-12-6**]).  She has WBC with significant left shift raising
   posibility of infection (sources include UTI and C diff). Hypovolemic
   shock was another possibility given her JVP was low and patient looked
   dry on exam on transfer to CCU, but currently she appears to be
   euvolemic.  TSH normal.  Pt is s/p RIJ placement on [**12-6**].  pt has
   peripheral vasodilatation on exam, indicating sepsis could play a role
   in hypotension.
   - place Swan ganz catheter, the numbers can guide us as to whether pt
   needs IABP or MVR
   - place A line
   - Treating infectious causes (see below)
   - continue to rate control Afib
   - f/u C diff
   - Cont Vanc/Zosyn until culture data back
   - follow Lactate and UOP
   - f/u Random cortisol
   - follow CVP
   - hold off on fluids now that pt appears euvolemic, will give more IVF
   if CVP <12
   .
   #. Sepsis: Patient with hypotension, tachycardia, WBC with left-shift
   and UTI at OSH suggesting sepsis. However, patient afebrile, other
   explainations for hypotension and tachycardia, UTI has been treated and
   now UA is clean and blood cultures have been negative. Concern for
   endocarditis, but negative blood cultures and RF normal.  However, ESR
   elevated at 53.  Patient with elevated alk phos and GGT, question
   whether she has biliary obstruction, leading to cholecystitis or
   cholangitis, given her significantly elevated WBC. However, blood cx
   negative so far, and pt has no abdominal pain.
   - Continue antibiotics for now (Vanc/Zosyn)
   - follow lactate and UOP  (goal 30cc/hr)
   - f/u Random cortisol
   - Daily BC
   - RUQ US today
   - consider pan-scan if pt tolerated lying flat
   - continue to trend
   - CIS
   - F/u UA & UC
   - F/u OSH micro
   .
   # RHYTHM: Afib with RVR.  In terms of etiology of afib, infection is
   one possibility.  Other etiologies include worsened MR (although LA is
   not significantly dilated).  TSH normal.
   - continue dilt drip, slowly wean down
   - continue metoprolol 12.5 QID
   - continue heparin drip for now
   .
   # PUMP: history of chronic systolic heart failure, and pt
s presenting
   sx were consistent with failure (SOB, orthopnea, edema).  Repeat TTE
   here at [**Hospital1 **] showed normal EF, but given mod MR, this EF could be
   overestimated.  Patient appeared volume depleted on admission, but now
   euvolemic.
   - hold off on fluids now that pt appears euvolemic, will give more IVF
   if CVP <12
   .
   # LEUKOCYTOSIS: pt WBC climbing to 27.6 this AM.  Unclear whether this
   is from infection or other causes.  Diff showed immature myelocytes, so
   also question bone marrow abnormalities.
   - check peripheral smear today (smear in [**Hospital Ward Name 1107**] lab)
   - f/u c.diff
   - f/u all cultures
   - continue to trend CBC
   - RUQ US today
   - consider pan-scan if pt can lie flat
   .
   # Elevated alk phos and GGT:  Question whether she has biliary
   obstruction, leading to cholecystitis or cholangitis, given her
   significantly elevated WBC. However, blood cx negative so far, and pt
   has no abdominal pain.
   - RUQ US today
   - continue to trend
   .
   # CORONARIES: Patient has unknown anatomy as she has never had a prior
   cardiac catherizations. However, MI is unlikely given lack of any EKG
   changes and negative troponins.
   - continue on aspirin for now.
   .
   # UTI: Citrobacter only resistent to macrobid, potential source
   - treatment as above
   .
   #. Hyponatremia: pt was initially intravascularly dry, so initially
   hyponatremia was mostly [**1-10**] hypovolemic.  currently euvolemic but pt
   continues to have hyponatremia, question whether this is from heart
   failure
   - continue to trend
   - hold off on fluids for now
   .
   #. Anemia: normocytic, normochromic with normal RDW. Most likely
   chronic diseases.  Fe studies are consistent with ACD.  Retic 1.5,
   indicating poor bone marrow response.
   - f/u  b12, folate
   - Trend HCT
   - check hemolysis labs again today
   .
   #. Creatinine: unknown baseline; cr 1.2, eGFR of 46 ml/min currenlty.
   Urine lytes showed evidence of pre-renal physiology, but now pt appears
   euvolemic after 1L fluid boluses yesterday.
   - continue to optimize BP
   - Trend creatinine
   .
   #Glaucoma:
   - continue home medications
   .
   #History of hypertension:
   - hold home lisinopril given pressures.
   .
   #Hypothyroidism - TSH 3.3
   - continue home levothyroxine dose.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: regular cardiac healthy diet
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:

   Multi Lumen - [**2129-12-6**] 07:00 PM

   and cell: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10133**]

   Cardiology Teaching Physician Note
   On this day I saw, examined and was physically present with the
   resident / fellow for the key portions of the services provided. I
   agree with the above note and plans.
   I have also reviewed the notes of Dr(s). [**Name (NI) 2589**].
   I would add the following remarks:
   History
   83 yr old white female with history of CHF and mitral regurgitation
   secondary to MVP now transferred with increased MR [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) 10150**]
   chordae, new AF, hypotension with evidence of infection.  Originally
   treated for UTI but WBC continues to increase.
   Physical Examination
   Mild resp distress.
   CVP 12.
   Loud murmur of mitral regurgitation at apex.
   Medical Decision Making
   Will place swan.
   On dilt drip and low dose lopressor to control VR.   Will discuss with
   EP ? TEE guided cardioversion or adding amiodarone.
   If deteriorates, consider IABP.
   Antibiotic coverage for ? sepsis with urine only source to date but
   concern re endocarditis.
   CT surgery to see re ? candidacy for mitral surgery.
   Total time spent on patient care: 30 minutes of critical care time.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of chronic systolic congestive heart failure (CHF), mitral valve prolapse (MVP), and mitral regurgitation (MR). She presented with generalized weakness and shortness of breath, and was admitted to another hospital before being transferred to this ICU for management of her heart failure and new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR). The patient continues to be hypotensive despite rate control, with increasing leukocytosis concerning for septic shock.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. MR: The patient has a significant tear at the posterior leaflet of the mitral valve, likely contributing to worsening MR. This could lead to further cardiac dysfunction and heart failure symptoms.
2. Hypotension: The cause of hypotension is unclear, but it is likely a combination of AFib with RVR, sepsis, and heart failure from severe MR. Hypovolemic shock was another possibility, but the patient appears euvolemic at the moment.
3. Sepsis: Despite treatment for UTI, the patient's WBC count is still increasing, indicating ongoing infection. Blood cultures have been negative so far, and there is concern for endocarditis, especially given the elevated ESR.
4. Leukocytosis: The patient's WBC count is climbing to 27.6, with immature myelocytes present,

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of chronic systolic congestive heart failure, generalized weakness, and shortness of breath. She has been admitted to the ICU for management of her heart failure and new onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. The patient's symptoms, including weakness, edema, and shortness of breath, suggest congestive heart failure with a likely etiology of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation causing improper filling of the ventricle. She continues to be hypotensive despite rate control measures and is showing signs of septic shock. Her white blood cell count is elevated with a left shift, indicating a possible infection. The patient also has leukocytosis, elevated liver enzymes, and a high ESR. There is a concern for endocarditis, but blood cultures are negative. The patient's electrolytes are also abnormal, with hyponatremia and hypokalemia. She has a history of hypertension, hypothyroidism, and anemia.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Congestive Heart Failure: The patient's history of chronic systolic CHF and current symptoms of weakness, edema, and shortness of breath point towards worsening heart failure.
2. Atrial Fibrillation with Rapid Ventricular Response: The patient's recent development of atrial fibrillation with RVR has led to hypotension and inadequate ventricular filling.
3. Septic Shock: The patient

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of chronic systolic congestive heart failure (CHF) who presented with generalized weakness and shortness of breath. She was admitted to Hospital3 and then transferred to Hospital11 for management of her heart failure and new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (afib with RVR).

The patient's symptoms indicate congestive heart failure, likely due to paroxysmal atrial fibrillation causing improper filling of the ventricle. She is experiencing hypotension, possibly due to a combination of afib with RVR, sepsis, and heart failure from severe mitral regurgitation (MR). There is also concern for urinary tract infection (UTI) and Clostridium difficile (C. diff) infection, as evidenced by leukocytosis with a significant left shift and positive blood cultures.

The patient's physical examination reveals bibasilar crackles, irregularly irregular rhythm, normal S1 and S2 heart sounds, a 2/6 systolic murmur at the apex, and 2+ lower extremity edema bilaterally.

Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count (WBC) with a left shift, elevated C-reactive protein (CRP), elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and elevated liver enzymes (AST, ALT, alkaline phosphatase, GGT). Blood cultures have been negative so

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of chronic systolic heart failure who presented with generalized weakness and shortness of breath. She was admitted to another hospital and transferred to this facility for management of her heart failure. Upon admission, she was found to have atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR), and a torn chordae at the tip of the posterior mitral valve leaflet with partial flail of the leaflet tip, leading to moderate mitral regurgitation (MR). The patient also has leukocytosis, hypotension, and elevated liver enzymes.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient has hypotension, tachycardia, leukocytosis with a left shift, and a urinary tract infection at the outside hospital. Although the blood cultures are negative so far, there is a concern for sepsis. The patient should be monitored closely for signs of infection, and appropriate antibiotics should be continued.
2. Endocarditis: Despite negative blood cultures and a normal erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), there is still a concern for endocarditis given the patient's significantly elevated white blood cell count and elevated liver enzymes. Regular follow-up of blood cultures and trend of inflammatory markers is necessary.

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of chronic systolic heart failure, who was admitted to the hospital for management of her heart failure and now presents with new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. She continues to be hypotensive despite rate control and has leukocytosis, raising concern for septic shock. The patient has respiratory failure likely due to pulmonary edema and pneumonia, and mitral regurgitation due to a tear in the posterior leaflet of the mitral valve. She also has elevated inflammatory markers, suggesting possible infection or endocarditis.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to pulmonary edema in the setting of severe mitral regurgitation and heart failure. Pneumonia is also possible given the opacity in the left lower lobe. The patient had labored breathing on 12/7, and an arterial blood gas showed worsening oxygenation, leading to intubation on 12/7.

2. Mitral regurgitation: The patient has severe mitral regurgitation due to a tear in the posterior leaflet of the mitral valve. This tear is likely contributing to worsening mitral regurgitation and heart failure. The patient's atrial fibrillation may also be related to the mitral regurgitation.

3. Sepsis: The patient has hypotension, tachycardia, leukocytosis

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, there are several potential medical complications that could arise for the patient. These include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient has a history of chronic systolic heart failure and recent symptoms of generalized weakness and shortness of breath. Additionally, the patient was intubated due to worsening oxygenation. This suggests the possibility of respiratory failure, potentially caused by pulmonary edema or pneumonia.

2. Mitral regurgitation (MR): The patient has a tear at the posterior leaflet of the mitral valve, leading to severe MR. This can contribute to heart failure and may be related to the patient's current symptoms.

3. Sepsis: The patient has signs of infection, including leukocytosis with a left shift, elevated ESR and CRP, and a history of UTI. The combination of hypotension, tachycardia, and rising WBC count raises concern for sepsis, which may be secondary to a urinary tract infection or other sources.

4. Endocarditis: Although blood cultures are negative, the patient's elevated ESR and CRP suggest the possibility of endocarditis. A pan-scan is planned to further evaluate this.

5. Hypotension: The patient continues to be hypotensive despite rate control, and the etiology is unclear. Potential causes include sepsis, heart failure due to severe MR, or other factors such as medication side effects or volume depletion.

6. Leukocytosis: The patient's WBC count is rising, and there are immature myelocytes present, raising the possibility of a bone marrow abnormality or infection. Further evaluation is needed, including a peripheral smear and follow-up of blood cultures.

7. Rhythm disturbances: The patient has experienced atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, which has spontaneously converted to sinus rhythm but then reverted back to atrial fibrillation. Infection and worsened MR are potential contributing factors.

8. Elevated liver enzymes: The patient has elevated alk phos and GGT levels, which may indicate biliary obstruction or cholangitis. However, RUQ US did not show significant abnormalities.

9. Anemia: The patient has normocytic, normochromic anemia with a normal RDW. Chronic diseases and ACD are likely contributing factors.

10. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is rising, suggesting acute renal failure, likely pre-renal due to hypotension and heart failure.

It is important to closely monitor and manage these potential complications to optimize the patient's condition and provide appropriate care.

   Assessment and Plan
   83 y.o woman with history of chronic systolic CHF with 2 week history
   of generalized weakness and shortness of breath, recently admitted to
   [**Hospital3 **] now transferred here to [**Hospital1 1**] for management of her
   heart failure and now new afib with RVR. She continues to be
   hypotensive despite rate control now with increasing leukocytosis,
   concerning for septic shock.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely from pulmonary edema in the setting of
   severe MR and heart failure.  Pneumonia is also possible given opacity
   in LLL.  Patient had labored breathing on [**12-7**], ABG showed worsening
   oxygenation, so was intubated on[**12-7**].
   - continue current AC mode
   - continue current abx (vanc, zosyn and flagyl) for broad coverage
   - f/u sputum culture
   - may need to diurese when pressure is better
   - daily CXR
   .
   # MR: patient was found to have [**Date Range 10146**] tear at posterior leaflet of
   mitral valve, likely contributing to worsening MR.  [**Name14 (STitle) 10146**] tear is
   likely a consequence of chronic history of MVP.  MR is likely
   contributing to her afib.
   - Csurge following (requesting dental records from OSH from [**Month (only) 1961**],
   carotid US)
   - be gentle on IVF to avoid flash pulmonary edema
   - may need to diurese when pressure is better
   - continue IABP support
   .
   #. Sepsis: Patient with hypotension, tachycardia, WBC with left-shift
   and UTI at OSH suggesting sepsis.  Also concerning for endocarditis,
   but negative blood cultures and RF normal.  ESR and CRP significantly
   elevated.
   - pan-scan pt today
   - Continue antibiotics for now (Vanc/Zosyn/flagyl)
   - follow lactate and UOP  (goal 30cc/hr)
   - follow venous O2 sats (goal >70)
   - follow CVP (goal [**7-18**])
   - Daily BC
   - CIS
   - F/u all cultures including c. diff
   - F/u OSH micro
   .
   # Hypotension: Unclear etiology but this is likely a combination sepsis
   and heart failure from severe MR (shown on TTE on [**2129-12-6**]).  Pt has
   converted to sinus rhythm, so afib with RVR is not playing a role in
   this hypotension.  She has rising WBC with significant left shift
   raising posibility of infection (sources include UTI, pneumonia,
   abdomen and C diff). Pt has peripheral vasodilatation on exam,
   indicating sepsis could play a role in hypotension.  s/p Swan ganz
   catheter and A-line placement on [**12-7**].
   - continue IABP support
   - continue pressor (neo)
   - Cont Vanc/Zosyn/flagyl until culture data back
   - Treating infectious causes (see above)
   - f/u C diff
   - follow Lactate and UOP
   - follow CVP
   - hold off on fluids now that pt appears euvolemic, will give more IVF
   if CVP <12
   .
   # LEUKOCYTOSIS: pt WBC climbing to 27.6 this AM.  Unclear whether this
   is from infection or other causes.  Diff showed immature myelocytes, so
   also question bone marrow abnormalities.
   - check peripheral smear today (smear in [**Hospital Ward Name 1107**] lab)
   - f/u c.diff
   - f/u all cultures
   - continue to trend CBC
   - pan-scan
   .
   # RHYTHM: Pt spontaneously converted to sinus rhythm after unsuccessful
   electric and pharmacological cardioversion.  In terms of etiology of
   afib, infection is one possibility.  Other etiologies include worsened
   MR (although LA is not significantly dilated).  TSH normal.
   - continue Amiodarone gtt
   - continue metoprolol 12.5 QID
   - continue heparin drip for now
   .
   # PUMP: history of chronic systolic heart failure, and pt
s presenting
   sx were consistent with failure (SOB, orthopnea, edema).  Repeat TTE
   here at [**Hospital1 **] showed normal EF, but given mod MR, this EF could be
   overestimated.  Patient appeared volume depleted on admission, but now
   euvolemic.
   - continue IABP support
   .
   # Elevated alk phos and GGT:  Question whether she has biliary
   obstruction, leading to cholecystitis or cholangitis, given her
   significantly elevated WBC. However, blood cx negative so far, and pt
   has no abdominal pain. RUQ US showed no significant abnormalities.
   - continue to trend
   - pan scan
   .
   # CORONARIES: Patient has unknown anatomy as she has never had a prior
   cardiac catherizations. However, MI is unlikely given lack of any EKG
   changes and negative troponins.
   - continue on aspirin for now.
   .
   # UTI: Citrobacter only resistent to macrobid, potential source
   - treatment as above
   .
   #. Hyponatremia: pt was initially intravascularly dry, so initially
   hyponatremia was mostly [**1-10**] hypovolemic.  currently euvolemic but pt
   continues to have hyponatremia, question whether this is from heart
   failure
   - continue to trend
   - hold off on fluids for now
   .
   #. Anemia: normocytic, normochromic with normal RDW. Most likely
   chronic diseases.  Fe studies are consistent with ACD.  Retic 1.5,
   indicating poor bone marrow response.  B12 and folate normal.  When
   IABP in place, there is a risk of hemolysis.
   - Trend HCT
   - check hemolysis labs today
   .
   #. Acute Renal failure: cr 1.2 on admission, rising to 1.6 today.
   Likely pre-renal given hypotension and heart failure.
   - check urine lytes
   - continue to optimize BP with IABP support
   - Trend creatinine

The patient's medical history and current condition suggest multiple potential medical complications. These include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient has severe mitral regurgitation (MR), which can lead to pulmonary edema and subsequent respiratory failure. Pneumonia is also a possibility given the opacity in the left lower lobe seen on the chest X-ray. The patient was intubated due to labored breathing and worsening oxygenation.

2. Sepsis: The patient has hypotension, tachycardia, and leukocytosis with a left shift, indicating a possible infection. The elevated ESR and CRP levels further support the possibility of sepsis. The source of infection could be urinary tract infection (UTI), pneumonia, abdomen, or Clostridium difficile (C. diff). The patient is already receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics.

3. Heart failure: The patient has chronic systolic heart failure, and her presenting symptoms were consistent with heart failure (shortness of breath, orthopnea, edema). The repeat TTE showed normal ejection fraction but significant MR, which can contribute to heart failure.

4. Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (afib with RVR): The patient has a history of chronic atrial fibrillation, which can worsen heart failure. The patient converted spontaneously to sinus rhythm after unsuccessful cardioversion.

Summary:
Based on the provided medical progress note, there are several potential medical complications that can arise in this patient's case. These include:

1. Shock: The patient is experiencing hypotension and requires multiple pressors to maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 60. This suggests a state of shock, which may be due to a combination of cardiogenic and septic factors.

2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient is oliguric with a rising creatinine level, indicating possible acute kidney injury. This could be due to pre-renal causes (such as hypovolemia) and/or acute tubular necrosis (ATN).

3. Respiratory Failure: The patient has a history of pulmonary edema and is currently intubated for respiratory failure. There is also an opacity in the left lower lobe of the lung on chest X-ray, suggesting a possible pneumonia.

4. Mitral Regurgitation (MR): The patient has a tear in the posterior leaflet of the mitral valve, leading to significant MR. This can contribute to heart failure symptoms and may be a result of chronic mitral valve prolapse.

5. Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, which may indicate an infection. Sources of infection could include urinary tract infection (UTI), pneumonia, abdominal infection, or Clostridium difficile (C. diff).

6. Endocarditis: Although blood cultures have been negative so far, the

Summary:
The patient is a 65-year-old male with a history of chronic heart failure who presented to the emergency department with complaints of shortness of breath and chest pain. The patient has been in the ICU for approximately one week and has been on multiple pressors to maintain blood pressure. The patient's condition has been deteriorating, with an increase in the need for pressors, oliguria, and worsening renal function. The patient also has a fever and increased lactate levels, indicating possible sepsis. The patient's family has made the decision to be do not resuscitate (DNR). 

Potential medical complications that can arise include:
1. Sepsis: The patient's fever, elevated lactate levels, and worsening renal function suggest possible sepsis. Prompt management is crucial to prevent further deterioration.
2. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's oliguria, elevated creatinine levels, and low urine output indicate potential AKI. Continued monitoring and appropriate management, including fluid resuscitation and possibly renal replacement therapy, may be necessary.
3. Cardiogenic shock: Given the patient's history of chronic heart failure and current hemodynamic instability, there is a risk of cardiogenic shock. Close monitoring of vital signs and hemodynamics, along with aggressive management of fluid balance and inotropic support, is essential.
4. Pneumonia: The patient's respiratory symptoms, elevated white blood cell count, and findings on chest imaging raise concern for hospital-acquired pneumonia

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 65-year-old male with multiple medical complications. The patient's chief complaint is not specified, but there are several significant events that occurred within the last 24 hours. 

1. Pressor requirement increased (neo+levophed): This indicates that the patient's blood pressure is still unstable and requires additional medication to maintain adequate blood flow.

2. The patient received 2 units of packed red blood cells (pRBC), normal saline (NS), and bicarbonate, suggesting ongoing efforts to improve intravascular volume and correct metabolic acidosis.

3. The patient is oliguric, meaning low urine output, with a fractional excretion of sodium (FeNa) of 0.1%. The osmolality is 334, which is consistent with mixed pre-renal and intrinsic renal injury. This suggests that the kidneys are not functioning properly due to both inadequate blood flow and intrinsic kidney damage.

4. A pan-scan is undecided due to the patient being too unstable to leave the floor. This implies that imaging studies may be necessary for further evaluation, but the patient's critical condition makes it difficult to perform these tests at this time.

5. The patient's family meeting was held, and they made the decision to make the patient do not resuscitate (DNR).

6. The patient's arterial blood gas (ABG) shows more acidosis and rising lactate levels, indicating worsening tissue perfusion and oxygen

   organomegaly.  No evidence high grade obstruction or perf
   Doppler U/S:
   LE: [**2129-12-8**]: possible DVT in posterior tibial vein right calf.  [**Month (only) 11**]
   represent old clot.  No acute DVT. Recommend repeat US in several days
   to re-evaluate
   CXR: [**2129-12-8**]: endotracheal tube 3.8cm above carina, intra-aortic
   balloon pump terminating 3.7cm below superior aspect aortic knob.  NGT
   terminates in the stomach; Swan Ganz terminate in RV.  Heart enlarged
   with slight improvement in left lower lobe atelectasis.  Persistent
   small bilateral effusions.
   Assessment and Plan
   83 y.o woman with history of chronic systolic CHF with 2 week history
   of generalized weakness and shortness of breath, recently admitted to
   [**Hospital3 **] now transferred here to [**Hospital1 1**] for management of her
   heart failure and now new afib with RVR. She continues to be
   hypotensive despite rate control now with increasing leukocytosis,
   concerning for septic shock.
   .
   #. Shock: etiology multifactorial from presumed sepsis and cardiogenic
   (acute MR, afib with RVR).  Low SVR, high CO, high mixed venous
   saturations suggest predominantly septic physiology.  Currently
   requiring multiple pressors and intra-aortic balloon pump to maintain
   MAP> 60.
   - cont phenylephrine, levophed to keep MAP > 60; consider adding
   vasopressin if necessary
   - wean IABP and pull today
   - d/c swanz-catheter and replace with triple lumen
   - monitor CVP (goal > 10, fluid bolus prn), Mixed venous sat (goal >
   70%), lactate and UOP
   - daily blood cx
   - CT torso today if pt stabilizes
   - continue empiric antibiotic coverage with IV and PO vanc/ meropenem
   - consider r/o PE if condition does not improve
   .
   #. Acute Renal failure: oliguric, cr 1.2 on admission, rising to 1.9.
   Likely pre-renal with overlying ATN.  Renal following, patient will
   likely need CVVHD but family has decided to limit care.  Patient with
   volume overload, metabolic acidosis but no significant electrolyte
   abnormalities
   - discontinue IABP
   - pan scan

Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of chronic systolic heart failure, who presented with generalized weakness and shortness of breath. She was admitted to Hospital 3 and later transferred to Hospital 11 due to worsening heart failure and new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. The patient continues to be hypotensive despite rate control and has increasing leukocytosis, suggesting septic physiology.

The patient's current conditions and potential medical complications include:

1. Shock: The patient is experiencing multifactorial shock, likely due to sepsis and cardiogenic causes (acute mitral regurgitation, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response). She requires multiple pressors to maintain mean arterial pressure above 60 mmHg, and consideration may be given to adding vasopressin if necessary. The intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP) should be weaned and pulled today. A triple-lumen central venous catheter should replace the swan-ganz catheter, and the CVP should be monitored (goal > 10, fluid bolus as needed). Mixed venous saturation should be monitored (goal > 70%), and lactate and urine output should be trended. Daily blood cultures should be obtained, and a CT torso should be performed if the patient stabilizes. Empiric antibiotic coverage with intravenous and oral vancomycin/meropenem should continue, and a pulmonary emb

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of chronic systolic heart failure presenting with generalized weakness and shortness of breath. She was admitted to another hospital and then transferred to our facility for management of her heart failure. The patient developed new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR) and was found to have a posterior leaflet tear of the mitral valve, likely contributing to worsening mitral regurgitation (MR). The patient also has evidence of sepsis with hypotension, tachycardia, leukocytosis, and a positive urine toxicogram suggesting urinary tract infection (UTI). There is also concern for endocarditis, but blood cultures have been negative so far. The patient's respiratory status has worsened, and she has been intubated for respiratory failure due to pulmonary edema secondary to severe MR and heart failure. 

The patient's condition is unstable with ongoing hypotension and oliguria, indicating possible acute renal failure. The patient's elevated white blood cell count (WBC) with left shift raises the possibility of infection, and there is a concern for Clostridium difficile (C. diff) colitis. The patient's leukocytosis may also be due to bone marrow abnormalities, and further investigation is needed.

The patient's electrolytes are abnormal, with hyponatremia that is initially hypovolemic but now euvolemic. There is also anemia

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is in the ICU with multiple medical complications. The patient has been diagnosed with acute renal failure, fever, alteration in elimination related to constipation, atrial fibrillation, hypotension, heart failure (acute on chronic), and hospital-acquired pneumonia.

The patient's vital signs show an elevated heart rate (118 bpm) and a slightly elevated temperature (38 C or 100.4 F). Blood pressure is within normal range. The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a respiratory support device.

The patient's lab results indicate elevated white blood cell count, decreased platelet count, increased creatinine levels, and altered electrolyte levels. The patient also has elevated levels of lactate acid and LDH.

The patient has multiple lines and tubes inserted, including an arterial line and central venous catheter. The patient is being closely monitored and managed for various conditions such as deep vein thrombosis, stress ulcers, and ventilator-associated pneumonia.

Overall, the patient is experiencing multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS) with involvement of the kidneys, cardiovascular system, respiratory system, and possibly other systems. It is crucial to closely monitor and manage the patient's condition, providing appropriate supportive care and addressing each of the identified complications.

   83 y.o woman with history of chronic systolic CHF with 2 week history
   of generalized weakness and shortness of breath, recently admitted to
   [**Hospital3 **] now transferred here to [**Hospital1 1**] for management of her
   heart failure and now new afib with RVR. She continues to be

   tissue dx and chemo

   - heme-onc recs
   .
   #. Shock: etiology multifactorial from newly discovered lymphoma,
   presumed sepsis and cardiogenic (acute MR, afib with RVR).  Low SVR,
   high CO, high mixed venous saturations suggest predominantly septic
   physiology.  Currently requiring multiple pressors.  IABP pulled
   yesterday.  Swan was pulled out yesterday as well.
   - cont phenylephrine, levophed to keep MAP > 60; consider adding
   vasopressin if necessary
   - monitor CVP (goal > 10, fluid bolus prn), Mixed venous sat (goal >
   70%), lactate and UOP
   - daily blood cx
   - continue empiric antibiotic coverage with IV and PO vanc/ meropenem
   .
   #. Acute Renal failure: oliguric, cr 1.2 on admission, stabilized to
   1.8 today.  Likely pre-renal with overlying ATN.  Renal following.
   Family is ok with HD in emergent situation. Patient with volume
   overload, metabolic acidosis improving, no significant electrolyte
   abnormalities
   - Trend creatinine
   - will give bicarb if acidotic
   - f/u with renal recs
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely from pulmonary edema in the setting of
   severe MR and heart failure.  Pneumonia is also possible given opacity
   in LLL.  Patient had labored breathing on [**12-7**], ABG showed worsening
   oxygenation, so was intubated on[**12-7**].
   - continue current AC mode

   - need to rule out PE when pt can get IV contrast
   .

   - contact Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] (OSH cardiologist) re chronicity of MR and whether
   [**Last Name (STitle) 10146**] rupture is acute
   .

   is from infection (sources include UTI, pneumonia, abdomen and C diff)
   Also concerning for endocarditis, but negative blood cultures and RF
   normal.  ESR and CRP significantly elevated.  Diff showed immature
   myelocytes, so also question bone marrow abnormalities. .
   Flu ruled out at OSH.

   - heme consult for further evaluation possible malignancy

   - f/u all cultures
   - continue to trend CBC
   - pan-scan
   - rule out flu

   - continue Amiodarone gtt

   - continue heparin drip for now

s presenting

   here at [**Hospital1 **] showed normal EF, but given mod MR, this EF could be

   euvolemic.
   - discontinue IABP support

   obstruction, leading to cholecystitis or cholangitis, given her
   significantly elevated WBC. However, blood cx negative so far, and pt

   failure
   - continue to trend
   - will give blood today for volume repletion given that pt is possibly
   intravascularly dry
   - give NS if pt needs IVF

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of chronic systolic heart failure. She presented with generalized weakness and shortness of breath, and was admitted to Hospital 3 before being transferred to Hospital 11 for heart failure management. Upon admission, she was found to have new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR). She continues to be hypotensive despite rate control and has increasing leukocytosis, concerning for septic shock. The patient also has presumed lymphoma, as evidenced by a CT scan showing extensive lymphadenopathy and multiple bilateral tiny pulmonary nodules. There is a possibility of malignant disease, but this appearance is uncommon in lymphoma. The patient has acute renal failure, respiratory failure, and mitral regurgitation (MR) with a tear at the posterior leaflet of the mitral valve, likely contributing to worsening MR. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Septic shock due to presumed sepsis and cardiogenic shock.
2. Lymphoma-related complications, such as infection or endocarditis.
3. Acute renal failure, possibly pre-renal with underlying acute tubular necrosis (ATN).
4. Respiratory failure, possibly due to pulmonary edema or pneumonia.
5. Mitral valve tear and worsening MR.
6. Leukocytosis of unknown etiology, potentially from infection or bone marrow abnormalities.
7. Hyponatremia, possibly due

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of chronic systolic congestive heart failure. She presented with generalized weakness and shortness of breath, which led to her admission to Hospital3 and subsequent transfer to Hospital11. Upon admission, she was hypotensive and required rate control for newly discovered atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. She also exhibited increasing leukocytosis, suggesting a possible septic shock. Subsequent investigations revealed extensive lymphadenopathy suggestive of lymphoma, acute renal failure, respiratory failure possibly due to pulmonary edema and pneumonia, mitral regurgitation caused by a tear in the posterior leaflet of the mitral valve, leukocytosis with immature myelocytes indicating possible bone marrow abnormalities, and hyponatremia potentially related to heart failure.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient's increasing leukocytosis and hypotension suggest a possible septic shock. Broad-spectrum antibiotics have been initiated, but further investigation is needed to identify the source of infection.

2. Lymphoma: The CT scan shows extensive lymphadenopathy, which is highly suggestive of lymphoma. Tissue diagnosis is necessary to confirm the presence of lymphoma and guide further management.

3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's rising creatinine levels indicate acute renal failure. Limiting care as per family decision, but CVVHD may be required in the future.

4. Respir

   83 y.o woman with history of chronic systolic CHF with 2 week history
   of generalized weakness and shortness of breath, recently admitted to
   [**Hospital3 **] now transferred here to [**Hospital1 1**] for management of her
   heart failure and now new afib with RVR. She continues to be

   #. Presumed Lymphoma:  CT scan consistent with lymphoma, but we need
   tissue diagnosis.
   - discuss with family re goals of care and whether they want to pursue

   #. Shock: etiology multifactorial from newly discovered lymphoma,
   presumed sepsis and cardiogenic (acute MR, afib with RVR).  Low SVR,
   high CO, high mixed venous saturations suggest predominantly septic
   physiology.  Currently requiring multiple pressors.  IABP pulled
   yesterday.  Swan was pulled out yesterday as well.
   - cont phenylephrine, levophed to keep MAP > 60; consider adding
   vasopressin if necessary
   - monitor CVP (goal > 10, fluid bolus prn), Mixed venous sat (goal >
   70%), lactate and UOP
   - daily blood cx
   - continue empiric antibiotic coverage with IV and PO vanc/ meropenem
   .
   #. Acute Renal failure: oliguric, cr 1.2 on admission, stabilized to
   1.8 today.  Likely pre-renal with overlying ATN.  Renal following.
   Family is ok with HD in emergent situation. Patient with volume
   overload, metabolic acidosis improving, no significant electrolyte
   abnormalities
   - Trend creatinine
   - will give bicarb if acidotic
   - f/u with renal recs
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely from pulmonary edema in the setting of
   severe MR and heart failure.  Pneumonia is also possible given opacity
   in LLL.  Patient had labored breathing on [**12-7**], ABG showed worsening
   oxygenation, so was intubated on[**12-7**].
   - continue current AC mode

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of chronic systolic heart failure and recent admission for management of her heart failure. She has been transferred to another hospital due to the worsening of her condition. The patient presents with generalized weakness, shortness of breath, and new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. She is currently hypotensive and has leukocytosis, which is concerning for septic shock. The patient also has presumed lymphoma, acute renal failure, respiratory failure, and mitral regurgitation.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Septic shock: The patient's hypotension, leukocytosis, and mixed venous saturation suggest a predominantly septic physiology. Close monitoring of vital signs, fluid balance, and lactate levels is crucial. Empiric antibiotic coverage should be continued, and source control measures should be implemented.

2. Lymphoma-related complications: The patient has presumed lymphoma, which may require tissue diagnosis and chemotherapy. Monitoring for any symptoms or signs of lymphoma progression is essential.

3. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine level has risen from 1.2 to 1.8, indicating worsening renal function. Close monitoring of renal parameters and consideration for emergent dialysis if necessary are recommended.

4. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is concerning, with possible pulmonary edema secondary to severe mitral regurgitation and potential pneumonia. Continued mechanical ventilation

   possibility.  Other etiologies include worsened MR (although LA is not
   significantly dilated).  TSH normal.

   - hold nodal agents in the setting of hypotension
   - continue bival drip for now, goal PTT 50-60 (PTT Q4h)

s presenting

   here at [**Hospital1 **] showed normal EF, but given mod MR, this EF could be
   overestimated.  Patient appeared volume depleted on admission, but now

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of chronic systolic heart failure. She has been admitted with generalized weakness and shortness of breath. The patient has been diagnosed with presumed lymphoma, septic shock, acute renal failure, respiratory failure, and mitral regurgitation (MR). The patient's leukocytosis is concerning for infection, and there are signs of possible endocarditis. The patient's rhythm is atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, which may be due to infection or worsened MR. The patient's cardiac function is compromised, and she has anemia. Other conditions include hyponatremia, glaucoma, hypertension, and hypothyroidism. 

Potential medical complications that can arise include worsening heart failure, septic shock, acute kidney injury, respiratory distress, further deterioration of the patient's lymphoma, and potential complications related to the patient's anemia and electrolyte imbalances. It is crucial to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, fluid balance, renal function, and response to treatment. Additionally, further evaluation of the lymphoma and its impact on the patient's overall health is necessary.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of chronic systolic congestive heart failure (CHF) who presented with generalized weakness and shortness of breath. She was admitted to another hospital and subsequently transferred to this hospital for management of her heart failure. She is now experiencing new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR), requires pressors, and has leukocytosis. The patient also has diffuse lymphadenopathy and pulmonary nodules on CT scan, but negative cultures. The etiology of her symptoms may be infection or neoplasm. She is currently receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics and doxycycline for possible rickettsial illness. Her condition is complicated by shock, acute renal failure, respiratory failure, and possible coronary artery disease. She has a history of glaucoma, hypertension, hypothyroidism, and anemia. The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation, and her code status is do not resuscitate (DNR).

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Septic Shock: The patient's high mixed venous saturations suggest predominantly septic physiology. She requires two pressors to maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 60.
2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine levels have increased from 1.2 on admission to 1.6 today, likely pre-renal with underlying acute tubular necrosis (ATN).

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of chronic systolic congestive heart failure (CHF) who presented with generalized weakness and shortness of breath. She was admitted to Hospital 3 and then transferred to Hospital 1 for management of her heart failure. Upon admission, she was found to have atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR), increasing leukocytosis, and diffuse lymphadenopathy. She also has acute renal failure, respiratory failure, and mitral regurgitation (MR). The patient's condition has been complicated by septic shock, pneumonia, possible endocarditis, and bone marrow abnormalities. She is currently on multiple pressors, intubated, and receiving tube feeds.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Shock: The patient is requiring multiple pressors, indicating a state of shock. The etiology of shock appears to be multifactorial, including newly discovered lymphoma, presumed sepsis, and cardiogenic (acute MR, AFib with RVR). Low systemic vascular resistance (SVR) and high cardiac output (CO) suggest predominantly septic physiology.

2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's renal function has deteriorated, as evidenced by an increase in serum creatinine from 1.2 on admission to 1.6 today. This is likely pre-renal with underlying acute tubular necrosis (ATN). Renal follow-up is recommended.

3. Respiratory Failure

The patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of chronic systolic congestive heart failure, presenting with generalized weakness and shortness of breath. She was admitted to another hospital and later transferred to our facility for management of her heart failure. She now presents with new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. The patient requires pressors, indicating a possible septic shock state, despite no positive cultures. She also has diffuse lymphadenopathy, likely due to lymphoma, and is being discussed with the family regarding goals of care and potential chemotherapy. 

The patient's respiratory failure is likely from pulmonary edema in the setting of severe mitral regurgitation (MR) and heart failure. Pneumonia is also a possibility given the opacity in the left lower lobe. She had labored breathing on 12/7, and an arterial blood gas (ABG) showed worsening oxygenation, leading to intubation.

The patient's acute renal failure is oliguric, with a creatinine of 1.2 on admission and 1.6 today. This is likely pre-renal with overlying acute tubular necrosis (ATN). Renal follow-up is planned, and the family is okay with hemodialysis in an emergent situation. 

The patient's leukocytosis is concerning for infection, but cultures have been negative so far. There is also a question of endocarditis, but blood cultures and rheumatoid factor

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of chronic systolic congestive heart failure (CHF) who presented with generalized weakness and shortness of breath. She was admitted to Hospital3 and then transferred to Hospital1 due to worsening heart failure and newly discovered atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR). The patient continues to require pressors for hemodynamic support and has an increasing leukocytosis, which is concerning for septic shock despite negative cultures.

The patient's medical history includes chronic systolic CHF, hypertension, hypothyroidism, glaucoma, and a history of medication allergies, specifically to hydrochlorothiazide. Her current medications include doxycycline, famotidine, fentanyl, heparin sodium, midazolam, phenylephrine, and tube feeds.

The patient's physical examination findings include intubation, sedation, anasarca of upper and lower extremities, lip ulcerations, tachycardia with frequent premature ventricular contractions (PVCs), bibasilar crackles on lung auscultation, soft and non-distended abdomen, 3+ edema in both upper and lower extremities, and mild traumatic ecchymoses on arms.

Laboratory results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell (WBC) count of 49.1 K/uL, anemia with a hemoglobin (Hgb) level of 11.0 g/dL, elevated creatinine (Cr) levels of 1.6 mg/dL, and elevated lactate levels of 3.4 mmol/L. Other lab values include elevated liver enzymes, decreased albumin, and electrolyte abnormalities.

The patient's assessment and plan include the following:

1. Diffuse lymphadenopathy: CT scan demonstrated diffuse lymphadenopathy and pulmonary nodules. The patient has been discussed with family regarding goals of care and whether they want to pursue tissue diagnosis and chemotherapy.

2. Shock: Etiology is multifactorial, including newly discovered lymphoma, presumed sepsis, and cardiogenic (acute mitral regurgitation, atrial fibrillation with RVR). The patient requires multiple pressors to maintain mean arterial pressure (MAP) > 60 mmHg and continues to trend closely.

3. Acute renal failure: Oliguric with creatinine of 1.2 on admission and 1.6 today. Likely pre-renal with overlying acute tubular necrosis (ATN). Renal consultation has been requested.

4. Respiratory failure: Likely from pulmonary edema in the setting of severe mitral regurgitation (MR) and heart failure. Pneumonia is also possible given opacity in the left lower lobe (LLL). The patient was intubated on [**12-7**].

5. Mitral regurgitation: The patient has a tear at the posterior leaflet

Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of chronic systolic heart failure, presenting with generalized weakness and shortness of breath.
- She was admitted to Hospital3 and transferred to Hospital1 for heart failure management.
- The patient now has new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR) and requires pressors.
- There is a concern for septic shock despite no positive cultures.
- The patient has leukocytosis, possibly due to infection or malignancy.
- She has acute renal failure, likely pre-renal with underlying acute tubular necrosis (ATN).
- The patient also has respiratory failure likely from pulmonary edema in the setting of severe mitral regurgitation (MR) and heart failure.
- There is a possibility of pneumonia given opacity in the left lower lobe (LLL).
- The patient has a tear at the posterior leaflet of the mitral valve, likely contributing to worsening MR.
- The MR is likely a consequence of chronic history of mitral valve prolapse (MVP).
- The patient's infection may be contributing to her atrial fibrillation.
- Other potential complications and conditions include leukocytosis, elevated alk phosphatase and gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT), coronary artery disease, urinary tract infection (UTI), hyponatremia, anemia, glaucoma, hypertension, and hypothyroidism.

Summary:
The patient is a 65-year-old female with a chief complaint of weakness and fatigue. She has been admitted to the ICU and has been on various medications including doxycycline, metronidazole, vancomycin, meropenem, and fentanyl. Her current vital signs show a temperature of 38.2 degrees Celsius, heart rate of 111 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 101/44 to 127/59 mmHg, respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. She is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a mode of CMV/ASSIST/AutoFlow, set tidal volume of 450 mL, respiratory rate of 26, PEEP of 5 cmH2O, FiO2 of 40%, and RSBI of 147. Her ABG results indicate a pH of 7.33, PaCO2 of 39 mmHg, PaO2 of 228, HCO3- of 91 mEq/L, and base excess of -4. Her blood work shows elevated white blood cell count (WBC) of 49.1 K/uL, slightly decreased hemoglobin (Hct) levels ranging from 33.2% to 33.9%, and increased platelet count (Plt) ranging from 188 to 203 K/uL. Other lab results indicate acute renal failure, elevated liver enzymes, altered electrolytes

   lymphadenopathy with pulmonary nodules.

   AM.. CT scan demonstrated diffuse lymphadenopathy & pulmonary nodules.
   Etiology may be infection (e.g. pneumonia, endocarditis) but negative
   urine, sputum, blood cultures, flu negative at OSH, and RF normal. ID

   All serologies sent except for an HIV test as patient is unable to
   consent. ID also indicated Doxycycline was unlikely to harm patient so

   as General Surgery declined LN biopsy. A peripheral smear as read by
   Heme/Onc was without clear etiology and the team did not feel this was
   likely to represent lymphoma.  ESR and CRP significantly elevated.  On
   Meropenem, day 5, IV Vancomycin, day 7, Doxycycline, day 3. PPD placed

   - f/u cx
s, all cultures negative to date

   .
   #. Shock: [**Month (only) 11**] be [**1-10**] presumed infection and cardiogenic (acute MR, afib
   with RVR) insult.  High mixed venous saturations suggest predominantly
   septic physiology.  Now off neo, still on levophed
   - cont levophed to keep MAP > 60, slowly wean down
   - monitor CVP (goal > 10, fluid bolus prn), Mixed venous sat (goal >
   70%), lactate and UOP
   - daily surveillance blood cx
   - continue empiric antibiotic coverage with IV
   Vanc/Meropenem/Doxycycline
   .

   1.3 today.  Likely pre-renal with overlying ATN.  Renal following.
   Family is ok with HD in emergent situation. Patient with volume

   - f/u renal recs
   - IVF
s titrated to UOP

   severe MR and heart failure.  Pneumonia is also possible given opacity
   in LLL.  Patient intubated on[**12-7**] in context of respiratory distress.

s presenting

   - continue ASA

   #. Hyponatremia: Improving.  Pt was intravascularly dry on admission,

   - Continue to trend

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of chronic systolic congestive heart failure (CHF) who presented with generalized weakness and shortness of breath. She was admitted to Hospital 3 and later transferred to Hospital 1 for management of her heart failure and new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. The patient is improving with less pressor requirements and improving leukocytosis, concerning for septic shock despite no positive cultures. A CT scan showed diffuse lymphadenopathy with pulmonary nodules. She has diffuse lymphadenopathy and pulmonary nodules on CT, and her leukocyte count is trending down. Etiology may be infection (e.g., pneumonia, endocarditis) but negative urine, sputum, blood cultures, flu negative at OSH, and RF normal. Infectious disease (ID) felt presentation was unlikely to be infectious but could not exclude it, so recommended CMV/EBV/HIV, anaplasma, rickettsial serologies. All serologies sent except for an HIV test as the patient is unable to consent. ID also indicated doxycycline was unlikely to harm the patient, so doxycycline was started on 12/10 for any possible rickettsial illness. Could also be possible neoplasm given CT scan & diff demonstrating immature myelocytes, but not able to confirm with tissue at this time as General Surgery declined LN biopsy. A

Summary:
Based on the provided information, the patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of chronic systolic congestive heart failure who presented with generalized weakness and shortness of breath. She was admitted to another hospital and later transferred to this hospital for management of her heart failure and new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. 

The patient has been improving with less pressor requirements and improving leukocytosis, concerning for septic shock despite negative cultures. She has diffuse lymphadenopathy and pulmonary nodules on CT scan. Her leukocyte count is trending down, and she has been started on doxycycline for possible rickettsial illness. 

She also has acute renal failure with an improving creatinine level, respiratory failure likely due to pulmonary edema and severe mitral regurgitation, and a history of chronic systolic heart failure with normal ejection fraction. 

The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation in assist-control mode. She is receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics, including vancomycin, meropenem, and doxycycline. 

Other notable findings include anemia with a normocytic, normochromic picture and reticulocyte count indicating poor bone marrow response, elevated liver enzymes, and electrolyte abnormalities. 

The patient has a history of chronic systolic heart failure, glaucoma, hypothyroidism, and acute renal failure. 

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of chronic systolic heart failure and a recent admission for generalized weakness and shortness of breath. She has been transferred to this hospital for management of her heart failure and new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. The patient's condition is improving, with decreasing pressor requirements and improving leukocytosis, but there is concern for septic shock. She has diffuse lymphadenopathy with pulmonary nodules on a CT scan, and her blood cultures are negative. The patient's laboratory values show leukocytosis, elevated C-reactive protein (CRP), and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). There is also evidence of anemia, hyponatremia, and hypothyroidism.

The patient's current medications include vancomycin, meropenem, doxycycline, famotidine, midazolam, and heparin sodium. She is intubated and on mechanical ventilation in assist-control mode. Her vital signs include a temperature of 37.9C, heart rate of 109 beats per minute, blood pressure of 119/51 mmHg, respiratory rate of 29 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98% on 40% FiO2. The patient's physical examination reveals bibasilar crackles on lung auscultation, mild traumatic ecchymoses on her arms, oral ulcerations, and significant peripheral edema.

The patient's assessment includes leukocytosis and diffuse lymphadenopathy with pulmonary nodules. The etiology may be infection (e.g., pneumonia, endocarditis) but negative cultures. ID felt the presentation was unlikely to be infectious, but could not exclude it. They recommended CMV/EBV/HIV serologies, anaplasma serology, tularemia serology, ehrlichia serology, babesia serologies, and PCR, b-glucan, galactomannan pending. Imaging studies include a CXR scheduled, pending. The patient has also been placed on doxycycline for possible rickettsial illness.

The plan includes continuing current antibiotic coverage with IV vancomycin, meropenem, and doxycycline, daily surveillance blood cultures, and daily CXR. The patient's condition should be followed closely, with attention to trends in CBC, renal function, respiratory status, and electrolyte balance.

Summary:
Based on the provided information, the patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of chronic systolic heart failure who was admitted for management of heart failure and new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. She has been improving but still requires pressor support. The patient's leukocytosis is concerning for septic shock, despite negative cultures, and a CT scan demonstrated diffuse lymphadenopathy with pulmonary nodules. The etiology may be infection (e.g., pneumonia, endocarditis) or a possible neoplasm.

The patient is currently on multiple medications including vancomycin, meropenem, and doxycycline for broad-spectrum coverage. She is also on levophed for blood pressure support and has a PPD placed. Her renal function is improving, and she is being closely monitored for any changes in her condition.

The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to pulmonary edema in the setting of severe mitral regurgitation and heart failure. She has been intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation. Sputum culture results are negative for infection.

Other medical conditions and complications include acute renal failure, which is improving, and anemia. The patient's sodium levels are also being monitored and managed appropriately.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management of multiple medical complications.

The patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of chronic systolic heart failure, who presented with generalized weakness and shortness of breath. She was admitted to a hospital and then transferred to another due to her heart failure and new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. The patient is currently in the ICU, where she has been improving with less pressor requirements and improving leukocytosis, but still requires assistance for her respiratory failure.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Fluid overload: The patient has anasarca (generalized edema) and fluid imbalance. Her urine output has improved, but she still has a significant fluid overload. The goal is to achieve diuresis of 1-1.5 liters in 24 hours using Lasix (furosemide) drip. If this does not work, ultrafiltration may be considered. The target CVP is 10, and the MAP goal is 65.

2. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine levels have improved from 1.2 on admission to 1.1 today. It is likely pre-renal with overlying acute tubular necrosis (ATN). The renal team recommends continuing pressors for pressure management and monitoring creatinine trends. The goal is to maintain urine output greater than 30 cc/hr.

The patient is a 37-year-old female admitted to the ICU with acute respiratory failure, acute renal failure, fever of unknown origin, alteration in elimination related to constipation, atrial fibrillation, hypotension, heart failure, and pneumonia. The patient's arterial line was stopped at 01:00 PM on 12/12/2129 and restarted at 01:30 PM on the same day. The cordis/introducer was stopped at 04:00 PM on 12/12/2129 and a multi-lumen line was started at the same time. The patient is still on levophed and is trying to wean it down. The patient's right internal jugular (RIJ) cordis was removed and the left internal jugular (LIJ) was placed. A culture was sent from the RIJ tip and purulent material around the line was observed. The family was informed and surgery was re-consulted for lymph node biopsy. The patient has been NPO since midnight in case she is getting a node biopsy. The patient's last dose of antibiotics was vancomycin on 12/12/2129 at 08:16 AM, doxycycline on 12/13/2129 at 04:00 AM, and meropenem on 12/13/2129 at 04:40 AM. The patient is currently receiving heparin sodium at 1,050 units/hour and norepinephrine at 0.3 mcg/kg/min. Other medications and ICU care information are provided in the progress note.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has acute respiratory failure, and the current ventilator settings include a set tidal volume (Vt) of 450 mL, set respiratory rate (RR) of 26 breaths per minute, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%. There is a risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to prolonged mechanical ventilation. Monitoring for changes in oxygenation and clinical signs of infection is important.

2. Renal Failure: The patient has acute renal failure, which may be caused by factors such as sepsis, hypotension, or medications. Close monitoring of renal function and fluid balance is crucial. Daily assessment of urine output, electrolyte levels, and creatinine clearance is necessary.

3. Fever of Unknown Origin: The patient has been experiencing fever despite receiving appropriate antibiotics. Further investigation is needed to identify the source of infection. Cultures from blood, urine, and other relevant sites should be analyzed. A thorough physical examination and review of all systems are important to determine the cause of fever.

4. Alteration in Elimination: The patient has constipation, which can lead to alteration in elimination. Stool softeners and increased fluid intake should

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of chronic systolic heart failure. She was admitted to the hospital due to generalized weakness and shortness of breath. She was later transferred to this ICU for management of her heart failure and new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. The patient's condition has been improving, with less reliance on pressors and decreasing leukocytosis. However, there are concerns about septic shock, as indicated by a CT scan showing diffuse lymphadenopathy and pulmonary nodules. Despite negative cultures and a lack of positive findings for infectious serologies, the patient remains on empiric antibiotic coverage with IV Vancomycin, Meropenem, and Doxycycline.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Shock: The patient is presumed to have had infection-related shock initially, but now there is a possibility of cardiogenic shock due to acute mitral regurgitation and heart failure. The high mixed venous saturations suggest predominantly septic physiology. The goal is to maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 60, and if the patient's MAP is very high, it may be time to wean off the vasopressor or use a pressure window for diuresis/ultrafiltration.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of chronic systolic congestive heart failure (CHF) who presented with generalized weakness and shortness of breath. She was admitted to another hospital and then transferred to this facility for management of her heart failure and new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR). The patient has been improving, with less pressor requirements and improving leukocytosis, which is concerning for septic shock despite no positive cultures and a computed tomography (CT) scan showing diffuse lymphadenopathy with pulmonary nodules.

The patient's current condition includes fluid overload, anasarca, leukocytosis, fever of unknown origin (FUO), diffuse lymphadenopathy, and renal failure. She is intubated and on mechanical ventilation, receiving multiple medications including vasopressors, diuretics, antibiotics, and anticoagulants.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Infection: The patient has leukocytosis, fever, and diffuse lymphadenopathy, which raises concerns for an underlying infection. The negative cultures may indicate antibiotic coverage, but further investigation is needed to rule out any infectious etiology.

2. Pulmonary issues: The patient has respiratory failure, likely due to pulmonary edema secondary to severe mitral regurgitation (MR) and heart failure. Pneumonia is also a possibility given the opacity in the left lower lobe (

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of chronic systolic congestive heart failure (CHF) who was admitted to the hospital due to generalized weakness and shortness of breath. She was transferred to this hospital for management of her heart failure and new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR). The patient is improving with less pressor requirements and improving leukocytosis, but there are concerns for septic shock despite no positive cultures. A CT scan showed diffuse lymphadenopathy with pulmonary nodules. The patient has anasarca (generalized swelling), hypoalbuminemia, and fluid overload.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 38.1C (100.6F), heart rate of 110 bpm, blood pressure of 90/44 mmHg, respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation of 96%, and she is intubated on mechanical ventilation.

The patient's physical examination reveals thick secretions with a bloody tinge, an irregular and tachycardic heartbeat with a systolic murmur, rhonchi on lung auscultation bilaterally, edematous abdomen, anasarca with fluid weeping from puncture sites, and bounding pulses. Neurologic examination shows evolving status, with the patient wiggling toes on one occasion but not responding consistently to commands.

Summary:
Based on the provided information, there are several potential medical complications that can arise for this patient:

1. Fluid overload: The patient has been diagnosed with fluid overload, which is indicated by anasarca (generalized swelling) and hypoalbuminemia (low levels of albumin in the blood). This can lead to respiratory distress and pulmonary edema.

2. Acute renal failure: The patient initially presented with acute renal failure, as evidenced by a high creatinine level. However, the renal function is improving, but careful monitoring is required.

3. Septic shock: The patient was initially presumed to have septic shock due to infection, but no positive cultures have been identified. It is important to continue monitoring for signs of sepsis and adjusting treatment accordingly.

4. Leaky capillary syndrome: The patient may have a leaky capillary syndrome, which is characterized by fluid loss from the blood vessels into surrounding tissues. This can contribute to edema and difficulty in managing fluid balance.

5. Respiratory failure: The patient has experienced respiratory failure, likely due to pulmonary edema and severe mitral regurgitation (MR). Pneumonia is also a possibility. Continuous monitoring of respiratory status and oxygenation is necessary.

6. Heart failure: The patient has a history of chronic systolic heart failure, and recent events suggest worsening heart failure. Optimization of diuretic therapy and monitoring for signs of fluid overload are crucial.

7. Atrial fibrillation: The patient frequently

Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of chronic systolic heart failure, who presented with generalized weakness and shortness of breath. She was admitted to another hospital and later transferred to our facility for management of her heart failure and new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR). The patient has been improving with less pressor requirements and improving leukocytosis, concerning for septic shock despite no positive cultures and a CT scan demonstrating diffuse lymphadenopathy with pulmonary nodules.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is intubated due to respiratory distress, likely caused by sepsis-associated vasodilation and leaky capillaries, pulmonary edema in the setting of severe mitral regurgitation (MR) and heart failure, and fluid resuscitation received earlier. The patient is on assist-control (AC) mode and will continue with daily chest X-rays. The barriers to extubation include pulmonary edema, de-conditioning, secretions and plugging, and anxiety.

2. Fever of Unknown Origin (FUO), Leukocytosis & Diffuse Lymphadenopathy: The patient's WBC count is trending down, and a CT scan showed diffuse lymphadenopathy and pulmonary nodules. Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of chronic systolic congestive heart failure, who was admitted to the ICU for management of her heart failure and new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. She has been improving but remains critically ill. The patient is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation. She has diffuse lymphadenopathy and pulmonary nodules on CT scan, positive for herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection. She also has anemia, hyponatremia, hypothyroidism, and elevated liver enzymes. The patient's medical team is considering a possible infectious cause for her condition, including generalized HSV infection, as well as other etiologies such as neoplasm or autoimmune disorders. The patient has been on multiple antibiotics, including meropenem and doxycycline, but no positive cultures have been identified. She is also receiving antiviral therapy for HSV.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient is already experiencing respiratory failure, which may be due to sepsis-associated vasodilation and leaky capillaries, pulmonary edema in the setting of severe mitral regurgitation (MR) and heart failure, and fluid resuscitation.
2. Pneumonia: Although the sputum culture has been negative, pneumonia cannot be completely ruled out, and the patient may require additional antimicrobial therapy.

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of chronic systolic congestive heart failure, presenting with generalized weakness and shortness of breath. She was admitted to Hospital 3 and later transferred to Hospital 11 for management of heart failure and new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. The patient's current condition is improving, but she remains in the ICU.

The patient's medical complications and potential medical complications include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient has been intubated due to respiratory distress. She has received mechanical ventilation, and barriers to extubation include pulmonary edema, de-conditioning, secretions and plugging, and anxiety. Continuous monitoring of respiratory parameters is necessary.

2. Fever of unknown origin (FUO), leukocytosis, and diffuse lymphadenopathy: The patient has elevated white blood cell count and diffuse lymphadenopathy seen on CT scan. HSV infection has been confirmed, but other infectious etiologies have been negative. Further investigations are needed to identify the cause of these findings.

3. Shock: The patient experienced presumed infection-related and cardiogenic shock. She is currently off norepinephrine but still on levophed. Close monitoring of blood pressure, heart rate, and urine output is essential.

4. Fluid overload: The patient has anasarca, likely due to hypoalbuminemia, congestive heart failure, and leaky capillaries from septic physiology. Goal diuresis is

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of chronic systolic heart failure. She presented with generalized weakness and shortness of breath and was admitted to the hospital. She was later transferred to another hospital due to her worsening heart failure and new onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. The patient is currently in the ICU and has been diagnosed with respiratory failure, fever of unknown origin, leukocytosis, diffuse lymphadenopathy, and shock. She has been treated with multiple antibiotics and antivirals, but no definitive source of infection has been identified. The patient's condition is complicated by anasarca, hypotension, renal failure, neurologic impairment, and electrolyte imbalances. Her current medications include meropenem, doxycycline, acyclovir, and amiodarone.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to sepsis-associated vasodilation and leaky capillaries, pulmonary edema in the setting of severe mitral regurgitation (MR) and heart failure, and fluid resuscitation she received earlier. Pneumonia is also possible but sputum culture has been negative. Intubation and mechanical ventilation may be necessary to support her breathing.

2. Fever of Unknown Origin (FUO): Despite negative cultures and lack of obvious sources of infection, the patient has persistent fever. This could indicate an underlying infection or another

   83 y.o woman with history of chronic systolic CHF with 2 week history
   of generalized weakness and shortness of breath, recently admitted to
   [**Hospital3 **] now transferred here to [**Hospital1 1**] for management of her
   heart failure and new afib with RVR. She is improving with less pressor
   requirements and improving leukocytosis, concerning for septic shock
   despite no positive cultures and a CT demonstrating diffuse
   lymphadenopathy with pulmonary nodules.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely from sepsis-associated vasodilatation and
   leaky capillaries, pulmonary edema in the setting of severe MR and
   heart failure, and the fluid resuscitation she received earlier.
   Patient intubated on[**12-7**] in context of respiratory distress.
   Pneumonia is possibility given thick secretions, so sputum cx sent on
   [**12-15**]. Preliminary results demonstrate 1+ GPC in pairs. PE remote
   possibility. Patient was on CPAP (setting: [**11-12**]) yesterday ([**12-15**]), for 4
   hours but was tiring out so put back on AC mode.  Barriers to
   extubation include pulmonary edema, de-conditioning, secretions and
   plugging, and anxiety. Versed & Fentanyl attempted for reducing
   anxiety, but short-lived effect. RSBI 110 this morning.
   - continue AC mode, try CPAP again today
   - reassurance to patient to reduce anxiety, can continue with
   anxiolytics/sedatives for symptoms
   - Continue diuresis, currently on lasix gtt at 2.5mg /hr
   - Continue current abx (meropenem, doxy) for broad coverage
   - daily CXR
   - f/u final sputum cx, AFB cx
   .
   # FUO, leukocytosis & diffuse lymphadenopathy: WBC trending down, 18.7
   this AM. CT scan demonstrated diffuse lymphadenopathy & pulmonary
   nodules.  Etiology may be infection (e.g. viral, pneumonia,
   endocarditis).  HSV positive, but given clinical presentation, unlikely
   to be generalized HSV infection.  Other infectious etiologies have been
   negative, including negative urine, stool, sputum, blood cultures, flu
   negative at OSH, and RF normal. ID felt presentation was unlikely to be
   infectious, but as could not exclude, CMV/EBV/Toxo, anaplasma,
   rickettsial serologies all sent & negative. PPD negative. Prelim AFB
   negative. Given patient
s functional status, HIV consent could not be
   obtained. Respiratory viral panel is negative. Central venous access
   resited to LIJ from RIJ on [**12-12**].  Cx from purulent material at RIJ and
   RIJ tip negative. Sputum sent [**12-16**], prelim demonstrating 1+ for gram
   positive cocci in pairs. ID signed off as of [**12-16**]. Could also be
   possible neoplasm given CT scan & diff demonstrating immature
   myelocytes, but not able to confirm with tissue at this time as General
   Surgery declined LN biopsy.  A peripheral smear as read by Heme/Onc was
   without clear etiology and the team did not feel this was likely to
   represent lymphoma.  ESR and CRP significantly elevated.
   - Meropenem 500mg TID, day [**8-22**]
   - Doxycycline 100mg q12H, day [**6-21**]
   - Acyclovir 400mg TID, day [**1-18**]
   - f/u any daily G Surgery recs; they will biopsy if "recovers from

   with RVR) insult.  High mixed venous saturations suggest predominantly
   septic physiology.  Remains on low dose Levophed, weaned to 0.09

   capillary syndrome, recommended pressors over IVF for pressure
   management.  Tolerating diuresis well.
